meta.content: Continuous studies from the previous paper on the intrinsic toroidal rotation scaling [Yoo et al., Phys. Plasmas 24, 072510 (2017)] are further investigated in KSTAR. We have extended the core ohmic rotation scaling in the co-current direction and the corresponding scaling shows a strong dependence with the ion temperature divided by plasma current (Ti/Ip). As a result, the measured intrinsic toroidal rotation scaling for ohmic plasmas scales well with Ti/Ip, regardless of the toroidal rotation direction.

div.h6: Experimental evidence of intrinsic ohmic rotation in KSTAR

div.div:
Continuous studies from the previous paper on the intrinsic toroidal rotation scaling [Yoo
et al.
, Phys. Plasmas
24
, 072510 (2017)] are further investigated in KSTAR. We have extended the core ohmic rotation scaling in the co-current direction and the corresponding scaling shows a strong dependence with the ion temperature divided by plasma current (T
i
/I
p
). As a result, the measured intrinsic toroidal rotation scaling for ohmic plasmas scales well with T
i
/I
p
, regardless of the toroidal rotation direction.

Recently, the intrinsic ohmic toroidal rotation scaling without any external momentum sources, magnetic perturbations, and strong magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) activities has been investigated in KSTAR to speculate an unrevealed origin of toroidal intrinsic rotation.
1
1. J. W. Yoo, S. G. Lee, S. H. Ko, J. Seol, H. H. Lee, and J. H. Kim, Phys. Plasmas
24
, 072510 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4991397
The intrinsic rotation in the magnetic confinement fusion experiments has been importantly recognized since the most effective external torque directed by a neutral beam injection (NBI) may not drive enough toroidal rotation for future burning plasmas such as ITER and Demonstration Power Plants (DEMO) so that to achieve the higher fusion performances, understanding of the intrinsic rotation characteristics is absolutely necessary prior to ITER operation. The ohmic toroidal rotation is one of the earliest examples of intrinsic rotation studies in tokamak devices, and the typically measured values of the core ohmic rotation are in the range of zero to a few 10âkm/s with a co- or counter-current direction depending on the experimental conditions. Here, the co- and counter-current rotation means the same and opposite direction to the plasma current, respectively. Note that the KSTAR tokamak is ideally suited for the investigations of intrinsic toroidal rotation phenomena excluding any unnecessary toroidal rotation damping effects including the neoclassical toroidal viscosity since the intrinsic non-axisymmetric field has been measured at extremely low level, suggesting at least an order of magnitude lower than in other major tokamak devices.
2
2. Y. In, J. K. Park, Y. M. Jeon, J. Kim, and M. Okabayashi, Nucl. Fusion
55
, 043004 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/55/4/043004
In addition, the toroidal rotation data in KSTAR are accurately calibrated utilizing a mode-locking, MHD, and the cross-validated diagnostics from X-ray Imaging Crystal Spectrometer (XICS) and Charge Exchange Spectrometer (CES).
3
3. S. G. Lee, H. H. Lee, W. H. Ko, J. W. Yoo, and KSTAR Team, Fusion Sci. Technol.
69
, 555 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.13182/FST15-174
The main purpose of this work was to report the general behaviors of the intrinsic ohmic rotation with the co-current direction since we further extended the intrinsic toroidal rotation data to the co-current regimes in KSTAR.

Figure
1
shows a typical example of core ohmic toroidal rotation characteristics with various plasma currents in the range of 0.3â0.6 MA. The toroidal rotation data shown in Fig.
1
are carefully selected among many ohmic discharges accumulated more than five years, and all data are accurately calibrated and/or cross validated as mentioned previously. The variation of the electron density and elongation are changed from 0.5 to 3.0âÃâ10
19
m
â3
and 1.2 to 1.7, respectively. The direction and magnitude of the core toroidal rotation strongly depend on the plasma current as shown mostly in the counter-current direction, and its absolute magnitude decreases with the plasma current. This is the main reason that the previous investigation of the intrinsic ohmic rotation scaling has been focused for the counter-current direction. The co-current toroidal rotation is also measured when the plasma current is higher and relatively lower electron density regime so that we further extended database in this area.

FIG. 1.
Typical example of the core ohmic toroidal rotation with various plasma currents.

Figure
2
clearly shows the measured toroidal rotation (V
Ï
) turns to a co-current direction when the electron density is reduced to lower density regime of about 0.75âÃâ10
19
/m
3
. The main diagnostics for the toroidal rotation measurement are utilized by XICS and CES, and the simultaneous measurements from both diagnostics are agreed well. A short beam-blip technique is applied for the CES diagnostic, and this method has been widely used for the intrinsic toroidal rotation studies unless there is a strong torque generated from the beam-blip.
3
3. S. G. Lee, H. H. Lee, W. H. Ko, J. W. Yoo, and KSTAR Team, Fusion Sci. Technol.
69
, 555 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.13182/FST15-174
Although a strong torque from each beam-blip is generated in Fig.
2
, the temporal behavior of the toroidal rotation before the first beam-blip belongs to a pure ohmic plasma phase and the corresponding scaling studies for this period is mainly considered in this work.

FIG. 2.
Direct comparison of the core ohmic toroidal rotation and ion temperature from XICS and CES.

Figure
3
compares the time traces of two identical discharges with the same experimental conditions to confirm the ohmic rotation direction more clearly even if similar results have been shown in Fig.
2
. The only difference between two discharges is the electron density, which is indicated with a blue shaded area in the ohmic plasma phase before Electron Cyclotron Heating (ECH) injection. The core toroidal rotation in the beginning of the plasma current flat-top phase starts in the counter-current direction for both the discharges with normal density conditions, the same as in the previous results in Ref.
1
1. J. W. Yoo, S. G. Lee, S. H. Ko, J. Seol, H. H. Lee, and J. H. Kim, Phys. Plasmas
24
, 072510 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4991397
, whereas their magnitude and direction are distinctively changed with the electron density. For example, in the lower electron density regimes about 0.5â0.75âÃâ10
19
/m
3
, the toroidal rotation usually turns to the co-current direction as shown in Figs.
2
and
3
. When the electron density is lower than 0.5âÃâ10
19
/m
3
, the runaway electrons are easily generated from the KSTAR plasmas.
4
4. C. S. Kang and S. G. Lee, Phys. Plasmas
21
, 072509 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4890461
Therefore, we usually keep the electron density higher than 0.5âÃâ10
19
/m
3
, excluding any runaway electron contributions in this scaling studies.

FIG. 3.
Temporal behaviors of the main plasma parameters.

Figure
4
shows the toroidal rotation and ion temperature profile measured by CES at 2.5 s from time evolution data shown in Fig.
3
since CES diagnostic provides entire radial profiles, whereas XICS measurement is limited in the core region.
3
3. S. G. Lee, H. H. Lee, W. H. Ko, J. W. Yoo, and KSTAR Team, Fusion Sci. Technol.
69
, 555 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.13182/FST15-174
A hollow rotation profile with a peaking about r/aââ¼â0.3 is clearly shown for shot 17â022, which rotates in the counter-current direction, whereas a flat rotation profile without peaking is shown in the co-current discharge (shot 17â016). Similar results have been summarized from many tokamak devices when there are intrinsic rotation reversals.
5
5. Y. Camenen, C. Angioni, A. Bortolon, B. P. Duval, E. Fable, W. A. Hornsby, R. M. McDermott, D. H. Na, Y.-S. Na, A. G. Peeters, and J. E. Rice, Plasma Phys. Controlled Fusion
59
, 034001 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1088/1361-6587/aa543a
Although the rotation reversal phenomena are also observed for shot 17â016 at about 1.65 s and for shot 17â016 at 3.0 s coincident with ECH injection, our main objective of this paper was to investigate the intrinsic toroidal rotation scaling. Note that the core toroidal rotation reversal experiments have been reported from many tokamak devices with the relatively slower toroidal rotation levels withinâÂ±20âkm/s or so,
5
5. Y. Camenen, C. Angioni, A. Bortolon, B. P. Duval, E. Fable, W. A. Hornsby, R. M. McDermott, D. H. Na, Y.-S. Na, A. G. Peeters, and J. E. Rice, Plasma Phys. Controlled Fusion
59
, 034001 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1088/1361-6587/aa543a
whereas this phenomenon hardly found when the toroidal rotation speed is higher than this level from pure ohmic discharges in KSTAR (see Fig. 1 in Ref.
1
1. J. W. Yoo, S. G. Lee, S. H. Ko, J. Seol, H. H. Lee, and J. H. Kim, Phys. Plasmas
24
, 072510 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4991397
). The maximum ion thermal Mach number defined as M
i
=âV
Ï
/V
i
is reached up to 0.25 from lower plasma current regimes shown in Fig.
1
, where V
i
is the ion thermal velocity.

FIG. 4.
Toroidal rotation and ion temperature profile measured by CES.

Previous investigations of the toroidal rotation for the counter-current direction have shown a strong dependence with T
i
/I
p
scaling, and the resulting slopes are â23 (Ref.
1
1. J. W. Yoo, S. G. Lee, S. H. Ko, J. Seol, H. H. Lee, and J. H. Kim, Phys. Plasmas
24
, 072510 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4991397
) and â18.
6
6. F. I. Parra, M. F. F. Nave, A. A. Schekochihin, C. Giroud, J. S. de Grassie, J. H. F. Severo, P. de Vries, and K. D. Zastrow, Phys. Rev. Lett.
108
, 095001 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.108.095001
This simple scaling is independent of the machine size and applicable for both counter- and co-current rotation so that we applied this scaling to our extended experimental data with co-current toroidal rotation data. In our knowledge, the ohmic toroidal rotation scaling with the co-current direction has not been deeply investigated and this activity may contribute to understand the unrevealed origin of toroidal intrinsic rotation. Figure
5
shows the resulting intrinsic ohmic rotation scaling with the co-current direction and the corresponding scaling is fitted well by T
i
/I
p
with a slope of about 17. The general characteristic is similar to the previous ohmic rotation scaling for the counter-current direction in the range of slower toroidal rotation levels below â15âkm/s where the experimental data also show some scatter behavior.
1
1. J. W. Yoo, S. G. Lee, S. H. Ko, J. Seol, H. H. Lee, and J. H. Kim, Phys. Plasmas
24
, 072510 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4991397

FIG. 5.
Intrinsic toroidal rotation scaling for ohmic plasmas with the co-current direction.

As a summary, we have successfully extended the core ohmic rotation scaling in the co-current direction to continue the previous investigation on the intrinsic toroidal rotation. Similar to the previous ohmic rotation scaling for the counter-current direction, the ohmic rotation scaling for the co-current direction also showed good T
i
/I
p
dependence. Therefore, we believe that the measured intrinsic toroidal rotation for ohmic plasmas scales well with T
i
/I
p
regardless of the toroidal rotation direction.

The authors would like to acknowledge the KSTAR Team and especially Dr. H. H. Lee and Dr. W. H. Ko for uploading CES data to the KSTAR data server. This work was supported by the Korea Ministry of Science and ICT under the KSTAR project contracts.
